questions.question: Which word below describes a property that scientists could use to classify matter?

answers.content: Transparent
answers.explanation: Transparency is an observable characteristic that can be used to group substances.

answers.content: Kitchen
answers.explanation: "Kitchen" is a place, not a property of matter.

answers.content: Breakfast
answers.explanation: "Breakfast" is a meal, not a property of matter.

answers.content: Yesterday
answers.explanation: This is a time reference, not a property.

questions.question: During the syringe investigation, what did students observe when they tried to compress water?

answers.content: The plunger moved easily all the way down.
answers.explanation: This would indicate the water was compressible, which it is not.

answers.content: The plunger could not be pushed further once it touched the water.
answers.explanation: Liquids have a fixed volume and are effectively incompressible under these conditions.

answers.content: The water turned into a gas.
answers.explanation: No change of state occurs simply by pressing on the syringe at room temperature.

answers.content: Air bubbles formed inside the water.
answers.explanation: Air bubbles would only appear if gas was introduced; this is not part of the procedure.

questions.question: Explain why a gas can be compressed much more than a liquid.

answers.content: Gas particles are far apart with large spaces between them. When pressure is applied, the particles can be forced closer together, decreasing the volume. In a liquid, particles are already closely packed, so there is almost no space to reduce and the liquid resists compression.

questions.question: In the syringe full of air, why did the plunger spring back after being released?

answers.content: The air expanded back to its original volume after the pressure was removed.
answers.explanation: Removing the force allows the compressed gas to push outward until it regains its original volume.

answers.content: The syringe was faulty and slippery.
answers.explanation: The observation is due to gas behaviour, not equipment fault.

answers.content: Gravity pulled the plunger outward.
answers.explanation: Gravity acts downward; it does not pull the plunger outwards in this context.

answers.content: The air inside turned into a solid.
answers.explanation: Air does not solidify under these classroom conditions.

questions.question: Give two different ways kitchen items could be organised and name the property used for each grouping.

answers.content: Example 1 – Group by function: plates and bowls together because they are used for serving food. Example 2 – Group by material: metal pots, glass cups and plastic containers are separated based on what they are made from.

questions.question: Which set of objects below all share the common property of being flexible?

answers.content: Pipe cleaners, pool noodles, Blu Tack
answers.explanation: All can bend or change shape without breaking.

answers.content: Coins, aluminium foil, car parts
answers.explanation: These are grouped by being metallic, not flexible.

answers.content: Window pane, empty glass jar, fish tank
answers.explanation: These objects are rigid and transparent, not flexible.

answers.content: Stop sign, post box, tomato
answers.explanation: The property they mostly share is being red, not flexible.

questions.question: Which statement BEST explains why the crumpled tissue inside the cup remained dry when the cup was pushed straight down into the water in Investigation 2?

answers.content: Air trapped in the cup takes up space and prevents water entering.
answers.explanation: Because gases occupy space, the air already inside the inverted cup forms a barrier that water cannot pass until the air is released.

answers.content: Paper towel is waterproof.
Water molecules are too heavy to rise into the cup.
Surface tension pushes the water away from the cup.

questions.question: During Investigation 3 (Gas Bag) the solid and liquid combined to make a gas that inflated the zip-lock bag. Which gas was produced?

answers.content: Carbon dioxide (CO₂)
answers.explanation: Vinegar (acetic acid) reacts with baking soda (sodium hydrogen carbonate) to release carbon dioxide.

answers.content: Oxygen (O₂)
Hydrogen (H₂)
Nitrogen (N₂)

questions.question: List any THREE observable properties or behaviours that can be used to identify a substance as a gas.

answers.content: Any three of: • has mass • has volume • can be compressed • flows (moves from place to place) • takes the shape of its container.
answers.explanation: These properties distinguish gases from solids and liquids and were highlighted in the lesson.

questions.question: Which investigation in the lesson BEST demonstrates that gases can flow from one place to another?

answers.content: Listening to kitchen and garden odours spreading through the air.
answers.explanation: Smells travel because gas particles move (flow) through space.

answers.content: Waterproof Paper (inverted cup).
Gas Bag chemical reaction.
Standing in front of a fan without touching it.

questions.question: Explain why a balloon filled with helium rises in air, whereas an identical balloon filled with ordinary air does not.

answers.content: Helium is less dense (has less mass per volume) than the surrounding mixture of gases in air. Because the weight of the displaced air is greater than the weight of the helium-filled balloon, an upward buoyant force pushes the helium balloon up. A balloon filled with ordinary air has nearly the same density as the surrounding air, so it does not experience enough buoyant force to rise.
answers.explanation: Density differences create buoyancy. This idea was introduced with the Larry Walters balloon story.

questions.question: When the bike-pump nozzle was blocked with a finger, the handle could still be pushed a short distance. This observation shows that gases:

answers.content: can be compressed.
answers.explanation: Air inside the pump was forced into a smaller volume when the handle was pushed.

answers.content: have no mass.
turn into liquids under pressure.
do not take the shape of their container.

questions.question: Draw and label a sequence diagram that shows the steps and results of Investigation 3 (Gas Bag). Your diagram should: • show the materials used • indicate where the chemical reaction occurs • identify the property of gases being demonstrated.

answers.content: Student includes labelled drawings of: zip-lock bag, vinegar, spoon of baking soda; arrows indicating addition and sealing; bag inflating due to CO₂; annotation such as ‘gas takes up space and expands the bag’.
answers.explanation: Full marks awarded when the essential components, reaction site, and property ‘gas occupies space / inflates bag’ are clearly shown.

questions.question: What does the term viscosity describe?

answers.content: How easily a liquid flows
answers.explanation: Viscosity is a measure of a liquid’s resistance to flow.

answers.content: How fast a solid melts
The temperature of a gas
The weight of a substance

questions.question: In the ‘runny-honey’ race, which ONE variable should you change to make it a fair test?

answers.content: Type of liquid used
answers.explanation: All other factors (amount, distance, angle, track) should stay the same.

answers.content: Length of the race track
Angle of the tray
Amount of liquid used

questions.question: If a liquid takes a LONG time to reach the finish line it has:

answers.content: High viscosity
answers.explanation: Slow-flowing liquids are highly viscous.

answers.content: Low viscosity
No viscosity
Changing viscosity

questions.question: List TWO factors you would keep the same to ensure your viscosity experiment is a fair test.

answers.content: Any two of: volume of liquid, distance travelled, surface of tray/tile, angle of the tray, starting temperature, timing method.
answers.explanation: Keeping these constant means only the liquid type affects the result.

questions.question: Would squeezable Vegemite have a higher or lower viscosity than regular jar Vegemite? Explain your reasoning.

answers.content: Lower viscosity, because it must flow more easily to be squeezed out of the tube.
answers.explanation: Less-viscous (thinner) Vegemite is needed so it can be pushed through a nozzle.

questions.question: Which of these everyday liquids is likely to have the LOWEST viscosity?

answers.content: Water
answers.explanation: Water flows much faster than the other options.

answers.content: Honey
Custard
Shampoo

questions.question: Draw and label three liquids with different viscosities (low, medium, high).

answers.content: Student provides three labelled drawings showing liquids such as water (low), oil/shampoo (medium), honey/syrup (high).
answers.explanation: Marks awarded for accurate representation and correct ranking of viscosities.

questions.question: Suggest ONE improvement that would increase the accuracy of your timing in the viscosity race.

answers.content: Use a motion-sensor or video slow-motion playback instead of a hand-held stopwatch.
answers.explanation: Electronic or video timing reduces human reaction-time error.

questions.question: In this experiment, the time taken for the liquid to travel the set distance is the:

answers.content: Measured (dependent) variable
answers.explanation: It changes in response to the independent variable (type of liquid).

answers.content: Controlled variable
Independent variable
Constant

questions.question: The famous ‘Pitch-Drop’ experiment has been running since 1927. Is pitch best described as a liquid or a solid? Give a reason for your answer.

answers.content: Pitch is an extremely viscous liquid because, although it appears solid, it eventually flows and forms drops.
answers.explanation: The formation of drops over time shows it can flow, a property of liquids.

questions.question: When a solid, liquid or gas is heated, the particles gain energy. What is the most immediate effect of this extra energy on the particles?

answers.content: They move faster and further apart, so the substance expands.
answers.explanation: Heat energy increases particle kinetic energy, causing the average separation between particles to increase.

answers.content: They become heavier, so the substance sinks.
They lose mass, so the substance evaporates instantly.
They stop moving so the substance becomes solid.

questions.question: In the ‘Amazing Self-Inflating Balloon’ demonstration, why did the balloon inflate when the bottle was placed in hot water?

answers.content: Air inside the bottle expanded, increasing its volume and pushing into the balloon.
answers.explanation: Heating a gas raises its temperature, causing it to expand at the same pressure or increase pressure in a fixed volume.

answers.content: Steam from the water entered the balloon and filled it.
The plastic bottle melted, creating more space for the balloon.
The rubber of the balloon becomes lighter when heated.

questions.question: Why does liquid rise up the tube of a traditional (non-digital) thermometer as temperature increases?

answers.content: The liquid expands more than the glass, pushing it up the narrow tube.
answers.explanation: Both glass and liquid expand, but the liquid’s expansion coefficient is larger, so it rises.

answers.content: Air bubbles pull the liquid upward by suction.
Gravity decreases with temperature, so the liquid is lighter.
The glass contracts while the liquid stays the same size.

questions.question: Water ‘breaks the rules’ during freezing because

answers.content: it expands instead of contracting when it changes from liquid to solid.
answers.explanation: Due to hydrogen bonding, the crystal structure of ice occupies more volume than liquid water.

answers.content: it contracts far more than any other liquid.
its mass decreases as it freezes.
it instantly turns into gas at 0 °C.

questions.question: What engineering feature is built into bridges to allow for the expansion and contraction of the structure with temperature changes?

answers.content: Expansion joints
answers.explanation: Expansion joints act like gaps or ‘zippers’ allowing the bridge deck to lengthen or shorten safely.

answers.content: Cooling fins
Solar panels
Wind vanes

questions.question: Explain why running the metal lid of a jar under hot water often makes it easier to open the jar.

answers.content: Heating the metal lid causes it to expand slightly, increasing its diameter and reducing the grip of the lid’s threads on the glass, so it loosens.
answers.explanation: Metals expand on heating; the glass jar expands very little, creating a larger gap between the two surfaces.

questions.question: Define ‘thermal shock’ and describe how it caused the glass to shatter in the video demonstration.

answers.content: Thermal shock is stress produced in a material when it experiences a rapid temperature change. In the video, cold water hit the hot glass, cooling the outer surface quickly while the inner surface stayed hot, creating uneven stress that cracked and shattered the glass.
answers.explanation: Different parts of the glass expand or contract at different rates, exceeding the glass’s tensile strength.

questions.question: On a diagram, show and label the direction of particle movement in a gas as it is cooled from 40 °C to 5 °C. Include annotations to explain how the change in movement relates to contraction.

answers.content: Expected drawing: many arrows representing rapid, random motion at 40 °C becoming shorter arrows closer together at 5 °C; annotation notes that reduced kinetic energy leads to slower movement, particles come closer, volume decreases (contraction).
answers.explanation: Answer should indicate reduced arrow length/density and textual mention of decreased speed and volume.
